headline: Judge blocks voting map favored by Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis
author: Lori Rozsa
sentences:
We look forward to defending it.?
Matthew Isbell, a Democratic redistricting expert in Florida, said he expects DeSantis and state officials will take their time in filing an appeal, hoping to run out the clock? and get so close to elections that judges will be leery of changing the maps.

Leon County Circuit Judge Layne Smith said the map drawn by DeSantiss staff is unconstitutional under Floridas Fair District Amendment because it reduces the impact of 370,000 Black voters in eight mostly rural counties.

Smith, a DeSantis appointee, said he would issue his formal ruling this week, noting that timing is crucial: Candidates hoping to run in the states 28 congressional districts face a June 17 qualifying deadline.

This year, in the midst of a pressure campaign from Donald Trumps former senior adviser, Stephen K. Bannon, DeSantis proposed his own map that eliminates the 5th District  a first for a Florida governor.
Conservatives were clamoring for a more Republican redistricting map, so one way to do that is to carve up District 5, make all of North Florida Republican and throw Black voters under the bus.?
We will undoubtedly be appealing his ruling and are confident the constitutional map enacted by the Florida legislature and signed into law passes legal muster,? Fenske wrote in a statement.
It follows the Florida-Georgia state line from Jacksonville west to the small town of Quincy, encompassing counties with some of the highest percentages of Black voters in the state.
In a good political year for Republicans, as this year is expected to be, Republicans could win 20 out of 28 seats in a state Trump won by just three percentage points.
The district is represented by Al Lawson, a Democrat who in 2016 became the first Black person since Reconstruction to represent most of those counties.
The 5th District was drawn by the Florida Supreme Court in 2015 and left largely intact by state legislators in this years once-a-decade map revision.
DeSantis communications director Taryn Fenske said that these complex constitutional matters of law? were destined for appellate review.
He later vetoed the maps submitted by legislators and called them back for a special session to pass his map, which they did last month.
This is all about Ron DeSantis trying to push this image of being a super conservative warrior,? Isbell said.
Ron DeSantis (R) that would wipe out a voting district in North Florida represented by a Black Democrat.
The DeSantis map also shrinks another district held by a Black Democrat in central Florida.
A Florida trial court judge on Wednesday blocked a congressional map favored by Gov.
